III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12507
Section Medical, dental and mental health care
Description • (1) An agency shall ensure that a youth in independent
living receives any needed medical, dental, and mental
health care as required in R 400.12413. Medical, dental,
and mental health care provided must be documented in
the youth’s record.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A has been asking to go to the hospital for 2 weeks. Youth
A was at the hospital 2 weeks ago and diagnosed with a Urinary
Tract Infection (UTI). Youth A had a bad reaction to the
medication that were given. The facility is understaffed and unable
to take Youth A to the hospital.
Investigation Youth A, age 17, was interviewed on 6/20/2025 via telephone.
She repeated the same information as the allegation. Youth A
reported she went to the hospital in May of 2025, and could not
remember the exact date but stated she had an infection. Upon
going to the hospital, she learned she had a urinary tract infection
(UTI). She was prescribed the medications, phenazopyridine
200mg to take for three days and sulfamethoxazole trimethoprim
every twelve hours for five days. Youth A reported she needed to
go to the hospital because she googled the medications she was
taking and discovered she was allergic to the medications due to
itching on parts of her body, legs and back and she was in pain.
She reported this was a side effect for the phenazopyridine she
was taking. She reported she needed to go to urgent care, but
staff told her she had to wait because other youths had dental
appointments, and their appointments were scheduled ahead of
her request. Youth A reported she did not like this decision and
felt her request was more urgent. Youth A reported she was told
by Program Manager to stop taking the medications and she
would be transported to the doctor the next day. She reported she
stopped taking the medication and she was not taken to the doctor
the next day. Youth A said the pain went away and the infection
went away on its own. Youth A reported she would have went to
the doctor on her own but that she needed a staff person with her
because she could not sign to see the doctor on her own. She
said an adult would have to accompany her because she was not
18 at the time. Youth A reported she felt she had no support and
at the time, felt unsafe. She reported she does not like the
2

program because every time she asks for something, she is told
no. Youth A reported she is not feeling any pain now and she feels
much safer. She reported no one in the program has ever
threatened her or had any physical contact towards her. Youth A
reported all of her needs are being met.
Chief Administrator (CA) was interviewed on 6/20/25 via
TEAMS. She reported Youth A entered their program on 2/3/2025.
She reported that the Independent Living Program (ILP) is not
responsible for youths’ personal transportation. Staff will assess
youth familiarity with public transportation upon admission and
offer assistance in learning how to use this form of transportation.
She reported that the agency will pay half of the cost of a city or
regional bus card. She said there are occasions that staff will
provide transportation assistance, at the discretion of the agency.
However, all youth under the age of 18 will be transported to their
doctor’s appointment because adult supervision is required to sign
for the youth. CA said this is in the youth handbook and Youth A is
aware of this statement. CA reported the agency is not
understaffed and have provided Youth A to several medical
appointments. CA reported the agency has twelve staff members
working in this program and the staff covers all three shifts. She
reported the agency goes beyond the contract requirements of
3PM – 7PM for staff. She said Youth A wants what she wants
immediately, or she becomes upset. CA reported Youth A breaks
curfew often and goes against the agency policies. CA reported
staff did take Youth A to the doctor on 5/27/2025, and Youth A
had a UTI. CA reported the reason Youth A wanted to go to the
doctor’s again in June 2025 was to find out if she was pregnant.
CA reported that Youth A found out she was pregnant. CA
reported life skills are offered to Youth A, and this is the part of the
program where independence is taught to all of the youths in the
program. She reported Youth A does not attend and has refused
to participate in services offered to her within the program. CA
reported Youth A never complained to her about an allergic
reaction from taking her prescribed medications. She said PM and
FCW would address concerns of this nature.
Program Manager (PM) was interviewed on 6/20/2025, via
TEAM. PM reported Youth A was transported to the doctor on
5/27/2025, by agency staff. She was given two medications to
take as she had a UTI. She reported the agency does offer
transportation assistance to the youth if a youth requests to go to
the doctor or urgent care, especially if they are under 18 years old
because an adult has to accompany them. PM reported that Youth
A never mentioned an allergic reaction to her from taking the
3

medications prescribed. PM reported Youth A requested to go to
the doctor again on 6/17/2025 stating she was allergic to the
medication and had started itching and was in pain. PM reported
Youth A never reported what type of pain she was having, but she
was transported to the doctor by agency staff on 6/17/2025, when
Youth A requested to go see a doctor. She reported the
medications Youth A was taking had already been used and the
reason Youth A wanted to go to the doctor was to find out if she
was pregnant. PM reported Youth A was transported to the doctor
on 6/17/2025 and learned she was 7 weeks pregnant. PM
reported Youth A does overact when she wants the staff to do
things for her immediately. PM reports Youth A is encouraged to
participate in her needed medical and mental health needs. She
reported Youth A’s response is to make threats towards the staff,
throw things around and Youth A can become explosive.
PM reported Youth A could benefit from mental health services as
she is diagnosed with adjustment disorder with mixed disturbance
of emotions and conduct as well as persistent depression
disorder. PM reported she believes Youth A’s unaddressed mental
health concerns are a major factor contributing to her emotional
instability and defiant behavior. PM reported Youth A has
demonstrated frequent mood swings and difficulty regulating her
emotions, which has compromised both her safety and the safety
of others in the program.
Foster Care Worker (FCW) was interviewed via phone on
8/15/2025. She reported in complying with the agency
expectations, a 30-day removal from the program has been
submitted for Youth A. She reported this will be difficult for Youth
A but Youth A’s behaviors are getting worst since she learned she
is pregnant. FCW reported that Youth A never mentioned to her
that she had an allergic reaction from the UTI, nor did Youth A
request to go to see a doctor for an allergic reaction from the
prescribed medications. She reported Youth A refuses to take any
medications for her mental health issues or go to therapy.
Documents Reviewed:
• Youth A’s MiSACWIS case record – Youth A, DOB
7/10/2017. She was placed in Federation Transitional
Living Program (ILP) on 2/3/2025.
• Youth A’s medical history in MiSACWiS – She was
diagnosed in 2018 for Persistent depressive disorder
(dysthymia), Attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder,
predominantly, inattentive presentation and posttraumatic
stress disorder. Youth A was diagnosed in 2021 for
4

Adjustment disorder with mixed disturbance of emotions
and conduct.
• Youth A’s doctor’s appointments in MiSACWIS and while in
her current placements are as follows: 2/13/2025 – Seen
for pain in left ear, Otitis inflammation prescribed Ceftin and
Flonase to be taken as prescribed. 2/16/2025 – pain in left
ear, referred to Advanced EMT and facial plastic surgery.
3/5/2025 – Chronic earache- ear infection, prescription
prescribed - follow up necessary. 3/19/2025 – Follow up
appointment, has additional allergies. Prescription
medication was prescribed. No follow up necessary.
3/24/2025 – Sore throat has strep throat. Prescription was
required. Youth is required to take the medication for 7
days and return to normal activities. 4/2/2025 – Received
Vertigo, no follow up necessary. 4/16/2025 – Follow up CT
scan for EMT & facial plastic surgery, sinusitis inflamed and
swollen area in nose. Prescribed medication and resume
normal activities. 5/27/2025 – UTI was prescribed
medications phenazopyridine 200mg to take for three days
and sulfamethoxazole trimethoprim every twelve hours per
day for five days. No follow- up necessary. 6/17/2025 -
Seen for pregnancy testing – 7 weeks pregnant.
Analysis Violation is not established. Based on interviews and Youth A’s
medical history, Youth A’s medical needs are being met, and the
agency staff is transporting Youth A to doctors’ appointments as
she was under 18 years of age during the doctors’ visits. Youth A
is offered medical services for her mental health needs and is
encouraged to participate, however, refuses to go to therapy or
take any medications for her mental health needs.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12503 Policy and procedures.
Section • (2) An agency shall have and follow written policies and
Description procedures for independent living services provided.
• (c) Agreement between youth and agency.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A checks have been cut, and Youth A is fined for breaking
curfew. Youth A cannot afford food.
Investigation Youth A, age 17, was interviewed on 6/20/2025 via telephone.
She reported the agency will not negotiate with her regarding her
fines in the program and the amount of money that is taken from
5

her check. She reported the fines and the amount of money being
taken is causing her to be hungry and not able to afford to buy
food for herself. Youth A explained she does not follow the rules
of the program, and she breaks curfew often. She reported she
leaves the agency at night around 1:00am to go visit her friends
because her friends work during the day and this is the only time
she gets the chance to interact with them. She said she always
returns back to the agency around 4:00am or sometimes later.
Youth A reported she catches the bus or gets rides from her
friends to get to her friend’s house. Youth A did not identify the
friends who give her a ride or pick her up. Youth A reported the
agency has given her permission to bring her friends to the
agency to visit her, but her friend has “records” and the agency
wants to approve them by way of fingerprints and her friends will
not complete the process. Youth A reported she has a bridge card
for food, but it’s been cut, and she currently gets $104.00, but food
is expensive. She reports her state check is $385.00 biweekly,
and her rent is $135.00 that is taken from her check biweekly
leaving her with $250.00, biweekly. Youth A reported up to
$100.00 is being taken from each check each week due to
breaking curfew and/or having contraband in the program. She
reported she has bills to pay, and the agency will not work with her
on these fines. Youth A reported she is aware that when she is
discharged from the program, she will get her money back, but
she needs her money now to pay her bills and buy food.
Chief Administrator (CA) was interviewed on 6/20/25 via
TEAMS. She reported the rules of the program were explained to
Youth A and initially Youth A followed the rules of the program and
the youth handbook. She reported Youth A reviewed the youth
handbook and signed and dated all forms. She reported the forms
signed were a copy of the youth’s handbook of the agency
explaining how the program works, consequences and fines if
rules are broken. CA reported $25 dollars are the fines for
breaking curfew and other program rules. CA reported the youths
always have enough money to take care of their bills and personal
needs as well as purchase food.
Program Manager (PM) was interviewed on 6/20/2025, via
TEAM. PM reported at no point, was Youth A deducted a $100
from her check per week. PM reported that although Youth A
payments are deducted from her check, the agency will never
deduct this much from a youth.
A ledger was sent of Youth A’s payments from the agency by the
agency financial department. The ledger had five independent
6

living saving/violations for $100.00. PM explained the agency
takes $25 out of each check for savings. The $100 that is reflected
from the ledger is the total amount of deductions for that pay
period of fines. PM reported that all youths in the program have
$25 deducted out of each check and it is placed in their savings
accounts through Federation Youth Services. She reported most
of the youths appreciate this and have often requested that more
be taken out. PM reported Youth A clearly understands this
process and is looking forward to receiving her savings check
upon discharge. PM reported the agency wants to be fair and
transparent with all youths and understand that youths need
money to meet their basis needs. PM reported Youth A was fined
for not following the rules of the program, but she will receive this
money back upon her discharge from the program as the fine
money goes into her saving account.
PM reported Youth A is well aware of this information, and she
signed and dated the program handbook/form that discuss the
fines and consequences for violation of the program rules. PM
reported Youth A receives a biweekly check in the amount of $385
which $125 is taken out for her rent and additional $25 is placed in
her saving account. She reported Youth A receives $240. If she
has any fines, and Youth A usually does, it is deducted from her
check. PM said all fines are $25.00. She reported Youth A was
receiving $291 monthly, her benefits have recently been cut due
to Youth A’s failure to complete interview/provide updated
documents to her assistance payments worker. PM reported she
believes Youth A is now getting about $104 in food allowance and
Youth A’s FCW has been encouraging her to complete the
documents and go to the interview but to no avail. PM reported
food is in the program for youths to access if the needs arises.
Foster Care Worker (FCW) was interviewed via phone on
8/15/2025. She reported Youth A is not interested in doing
anything in the program to help herself and that a 30-day
replacement letter has been submitted for another placement for
Youth A. A Team Decision Making (TDM) meeting has been set
to assist in making a plan and decision for Youth A’s next
placement. FCW reported that when Youth A is discharged from
the program she will have over $3,000 in her account from
savings and from a relative who left her some money. FCW
reported that Youth A is never hungry or needs food and that she
takes Youth A grocery shopping when she is low on food. FCW
also reported the program has extra food the youths can eat if
they are low on food.
7

DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• Agency Supportive Housing Handbook – This is the
handbook provided to all youths that explains the program
statement, rules, consequences, fines, transportation,
stipends, etc. along with forms to the youth acknowledging
receiving the booklet and signing the forms that are
required.
• Agreement between Youth A and agency – The contract
agreement was signed and dated by Youth A on 2/4/2025
and witnessed by staff.
• Youth A’s agency payment Ledger – the ledger had a
balance of $800 from 4/18/2025 – 5/16/2025.
• 30-day replacement letter for violation of program rules –
this was dated 7/10/2025. A TDM is scheduled for
8/14/2025.
Analysis Violation is not established. The policies and procedures were
explained to Youth A, and she signed and dated the contract
agreement on 2/4/2025. Youth A admitted to violating the policies
and procedures of the program and thus doing so is fined $25 as
a consequence. PM reported the agency will never take a youth’s
entire check for fines. PM and FCW reported if any youth are low
in food, additional food is kept in the program for youth’s needs.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
